supporting_quotes: Simbine returned to Portuguese East Africa in 1973, joining the Mozambican Liberation Front (FRELIMO) and working as a schoolteacher.
Following Mozambique's independence in 1975, Simbine was appointed Mozambican's first Minister of Education and Culture on 25 June 1975.
During her tenure, the number of students enrolled in primary and secondary schools rose from about 40 per cent of all school-aged children to over 90 per cent for males and 75 per cent for females.
She is the only woman in modern history to have served as First Lady of two countries: South Africa and Mozambique.
She is the widow of former President of Mozambique Samora Machel (1975–1986)
Graça Machel received the 1992 Africa Prize, awarded annually to an individual who has contributed to the goal of eliminating hunger in Africa by the year 2000.
Forum for African Women Educationalists (FAWE), co-founder and former member of the board (since 1992)
Foundation for Community Development (FDC), founder and president (since 1994)
Machel received the 1995 Nansen Medal from the United Nations in recognition of her longstanding humanitarian work, particularly on behalf of refugee children.
In 1997, Machel was honored with the Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire by Queen Elizabeth II for her contributions and services in the field of human rights protection.
Dame Grand Cross of the Order of Isabella the Catholic (GYC), 1997 (Spain).
In the same year, she received the Global Citizen Award of the New England Circle.
InterAction's Humanitarian Award, 1997.

Graça Machel Mandela married her second husband, Nelson Mandela, in Johannesburg on 18 July 1998, Mandela's 80th birthday. At the time, Mandela was serving as the first post-apartheid president of South Africa.
Machel was one of the two winners of the 1998 North–South Prize awarded by the North-South Centre of the Council of Europe.

roles: Princess of Asturias Award (International Cooperation) recipient
supporting_quotes: Princess of Asturias Award (International Cooperation), 1998 (Spain).
United Nations Foundation, member of the board (1998–2007)
Machel was chancellor of the University of Cape Town from 1999 to 2019.
She was chancellor of the University of Cape Town between 1999 and 2019.
Principle Capital Group, non-executive member of the board of directors (since 2004)
World's Children's Prize (together with Nelson Mandela), 2005.

roles: Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters recipient
supporting_quotes: Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters (Hon. DHL) from the University of Massachusetts, 2006 (USA).
On 18 July 2007 in Johannesburg, South Africa, Nelson Mandela, Graça Machel, and Desmond Tutu convened The Elders.
Deputy Chairs: Ban Ki-moon, Graça Machel
PME African Infrastructure Opportunities, senior advisor (since 2014), independent non-executive member of the board of directors (2007–2014)

roles: chairwoman of the board of trustees
supporting_quotes: ACCORD, chairwoman of the board of trustees (since 2008)
Graça Machel elected chair of ACCORD Board of Trustees ACCORD, press release 18 December 2008.

organizations: High-Level Taskforce on Innovative International Financing for Health Systems
supporting_quotes: From 2008 until 2009, she was a member of the High-Level Taskforce on Innovative International Financing for Health Systems, co-chaired by Gordon Brown and Robert Zoellick.

roles: Doctor of Philosophy honoris causa recipient
supporting_quotes: Doctor of Philosophy honoris causa (DPhil h.c.) from the University of Stellenbosch, 2008 (South Africa).
Doctor honoris causa (Dr. h.c.) by University of Barcelona, 2008 (Spain).
Doctor honoris causa (Dr. h.c.) by University of Évora, 2008 (Portugal).
In 2009, Machel was appointed to the Commonwealth of Nations' Eminent Persons Group.

roles: Decade Child Rights Hero recipient (with Nelson Mandela)
supporting_quotes: Decade Child Rights Hero (together with Nelson Mandela) by 7.1 million children through a Global Vote, organized as part of the educational World's Children's Prize Program, 2010.

organizations: School of Oriental and African Studies
supporting_quotes: She was named president of the School of Oriental and African Studies at the University of London in 2012.

organizations: The Partnership for Maternal, Newborn & Child Health
supporting_quotes: She served as the Chair of The Partnership for Maternal, Newborn & Child Health (PMNCH) from 2013-2018.
PME African Infrastructure Opportunities, senior advisor (since 2014), independent non-executive member of the board of directors (2007–2014)

roles: Doctor in Laws honoris causa recipient
supporting_quotes: Doctor in Laws honoris causa (LL.D. h.c.) by Trinity College Dublin, 2015 (Ireland).
In January 2016, she was also appointed by United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to the High-level Advisory Group for Every Woman Every Child.
On 17 January 2016, she was appointed as a Sustainable Development Goals Advocate alongside 16 others, all appointed by Secretary-General of the United Nations
In 2016, Machel was named chancellor of the African Leadership University, a role that she still holds today.
In July 2017, Machel was elected an Honorary Fellow of the British Academy (HonFBA), the United Kingdom's national academy for the humanities and social sciences.
In 2018, she was awarded by the World Health Organization for her contributions to the health and well-being of women, children and adolescents.
World Health Organization Gold Medal, 2018 (WHO).
Doctor honoris causa (Dr. h.c.) by Leiden University, 2021 (Netherlands).
Graça Machel is a member of the Africa Progress Panel (APP), a group of ten distinguished individuals who advocate at the highest levels for equitable and sustainable development in Africa.

organizations: Girls Not Brides: The Global Partnership to End Child Marriage
supporting_quotes: Machel has been particularly involved in The Elders' work on child marriage, including the founding of Girls Not Brides: The Global Partnership to End Child Marriage.

roles: expert author for Impact of Armed Conflict on Children report
supporting_quotes: Following her retirement from the Mozambique ministry, Machel was appointed as the expert in charge of producing the groundbreaking United Nations report on the impact of armed conflict on children.
International Crisis Group (ICG), former member of the board of trustees
Major award from CARE as result-longstanding work on behalf of children.
She attended Methodist mission schools before gaining a scholarship to the University of Lisbon in Portugal, where she studied German and first became involved in independence issues.
